Title: Prj_4639 - User Research tool (unmoderated/usability testing)
Description: The User Centred Design Team is looking to procure a tool to support unmoderated remote user research during the Covid-19 pandemic, and thereafter, to increase the pool of participants available to us to undertake research.  The tool should enable researchers to set pre-defined usability tests for prototypes, wireframes and beta websites to ensure our digital products are well designed and fit for purpose.  The tool itself should be able to capture qualitative and quantitative feedback from participants to enable us to assess 'what' users do when they interact with a product and also 'why' they do it.  Typical outputs from the tests include narrated video or transcript from the participant whilst they interact with the product;  plus web analytics (time to complete tasks, rate of abandonment), heatmaps and clickpaths of interactions.  Most of the tools we have identified are websites, however we are also looking for a tool with the supplier to recruit from their pool of participants, so we acknowledge there may be an ongoing 'service' element to it (which ideally we would like included within our subscription)
Attachments: [REDACTED] Order Form - Prj_4639 - User Research tool FINAL VERSION (002) (_1403062_1.pdf

Good horticultural maintenance of the hedge contributes to the quality of the surroundings.  They also contribute to the individuality of each area. Title: Safe Supported Accommodation for victims of Domestic Abuse
Description: The proposed service will provide support for: â¢ people and their children who have experienced domestic abuse, or who are at risk of being abused; and  â¢ who are also in need of short-term, safe, supported accommodation.  21 units of accommodation, will be available for the provision of the service. This is a refuge for women and children and consists of 20 self-contained flats and one self-contained bedsit, usually used for emergencies.  The successful provider will need to sign a Service Level Agreement with the Housing Association landlord of the property.   Additionally, the successful provider will be expected to provide: â¢  a minimum of 41 additional units which can be a mixture of another refuge provision, safe, dispersed properties, or smaller blocks of accommodation; these will be funded through rental income and housing benefit; and  â¢ a further 8 units of safe accommodation, as a minimum, by the end of the first 2 years of the contract period .i.e. a minimum of 70 units in total.   The accommodation offer should comply with the following constraints:  â¢ units must be in different locations across the city to offer choice and safety. â¢ be a mix of furnished, self-contained bedsits, plus1, 2 and 3 bedroom units, i.e. not shared accommodation. â¢ Some properties / units should be included that are adapted, or can be adapted to address accessibility issues for people with physical and/or sensory impairments, including some units which have wheelchair access;  â¢ Include, or be able to include target hardening measures; and  â¢ provide a concierge service in all accommodation that is of a refuge type i.e. not dispersed. A flexible and responsive out of hours on call service would need to be made available for all units that are dispersed, to provide advice and support, including to those onsite, where required. All concierge posts in women only provision will be female.

Title: Provision of Business Technical Support
Description:
Digital Innovation for Growth (DIfG) is a fully funded programme that runs across the South Yorkshire Mayoral Combined authority, to help businesses adopt technology and innovation. The aim is to help these organisations access and understand the different technologies that are available to them to maximise efficiency and adopt new ways of working. 
 
It is part-financed by the England European Regional Development Fund as part of the European Structural and Investment Funds Growth Programme 2014-2020. Organisations are linked with experts from Sheffield Hallam University as well as having access the new Makerlab at DMC 02 to test their ideas and see what is possible.  

Barnsley Council is seeking a provider to deliver the technical business support to DIFG beneficiary businesses within the Makerlab, and to curate a programme and content for a series of events between March 2022 and June 2023. The Makerlab operating hours will be Monday to Friday 9am - 5pm and technical support is required for any business wishing to access the space during these hours on a pre-booked basis. This support will include assessment of the beneficiaries' challenge and proposed solution (where one exists), and the provision of support to develop ideas further using the on site facilities and their technical expertise. The provider will also be expected to ensure that beneficiaries use the facility safely and within all health and safety guidance, following any mandatory training that may be required to access the equipment. 
Additionally, the provider will be required to develop a 16 month programme of activity to deliver a range of online and offline events using the Makerlab and other DMC spaces that share 'art of the possible' examples of digital innovation.

Title: Review of Community Infrastructure Levy and Local Plan viability
Description:
Test Valley Borough Council is inviting consultants to provide quotes for two connected areas of work. The first part is a review of the Council's adopted Community Infrastructure Schedule Charging Schedule which commenced operation on 1st August 2016. This is to ensure it is up to date, reflects market conditions, takes account of new national and local requirements and evidence since adoption and does not render development unviable while maximising the potential community benefits resulting from growth in the Borough. The BNP Paribas CIL Viability Study (2014) is the evidence base for the Council's adopted CIL Charging Schedule.

Alongside this the second part of the work will be linked to the review of the Local Plan and the draft local plan requirements, in terms of whole plan viability, and the viability of any future site allocations.

It is anticipated that the chosen consultant will support the Council through representation at a CIL Examination and/or Local Plan Examination and this should be reflected in the costs of providing a service.

Further details are available in the brief which is available at https://uk.eu-supply.com/app/rfq/rwlentrance_s.asp?PID=46909&B=UK

Title: INVITATION TO TENDER FOR CREATION OF NEW NATIVE WOODLAND AT CASTLE FARM AND HEGGS FARM, ARKENGARTHDALE
Description:
We are seeking tenders for all aspects of new native woodland creation at Heggs Farm and Castle Farm near Reeth in Arkengarthdale. The is 32 ha in total covering land on the two adjacent farms. 
The project involves creation of an access track (quad bike access, involving no materials brought to site), ground preparation (incl. bracken control), fence removal, new fencing and tree planting, according to a detailed specification.  
In total, 33630 trees and shrubs will be planted and protected. The density of the planting will vary with areas of shrubs and open ground. The lower section of the site will be planted at 1600 stems per ha, whilst the higher area will be planted at 1100 stems per ha. The area will not be made rabbit proof so the trees will be individually protected.  The area to be planted will primarily be dictated by the ground conditions and the existing tree cover on the site. A maximum of 20% of the area will be left as open space. The open space will be around footpaths, archaeological features, existing priority habitats and rocky areas where the soil is very shallow.
The scheme has been through the EIA determination process and any other consents will be in place prior to works starting. 
Payments will be made and contracts entered into with the Yorkshire Dales National Park Authority.
The full tender document with detailed information and instructions can be found on the Yorkshire Dales National Park Authority website www.yorkshiredales.org.uk/park-authority/our-service-to-you/access-to-information/open-data/contracts-and-tenders/

The tender must be returned in an envelope to the Director of Corporate Services, Yorkshire Dales National Park Authority, Yoredale, Bainbridge, Leyburn, North Yorkshire DL8 3EL, on or before noon on 3rd June, 2022. If tenders are delivered by hand a receipt should be obtained. The tender envelope and its franking must not bear any indication of the tenderer's identity and the envelope must only be marked "Tender for New Native Woodland Schemes at Castle Farm and Heggs Farm, Arkengarthdale." 

Electronic tenders, if preferred, should be sent to procurement@yorkshiredales.org.uk with the title stating "Tender for New Native Woodland Schemes at Castle Farm and Heggs Farm, Arkengarthdale" and must be received by noon on 3rd June, 2022.
Attachments: Invitation to Tender Heggs Castle FINAL.doc

Description:
The National Archives (TNA) is seeking expressions of interest from potential partners to digitise and to publish online Colonial Office, Foreign Office and Overseas Development records relating to twentieth century environmental history. The contract award would include a commercial license to publish online digital images and associated metadata, and a requirement to undertake all the necessary activities to make that possible - including conservation, digital image capture, use of metadata to allow for meaningful searches of the records, and online publication. TNA expects that the appointed Supplier will deliver the contract at NIL cost to TNA, and will also deliver a royalty return to TNA during the contract period, in consideration for the licence to publish the Collection. 

Environmental History is the study of how humans have interacted with the environment in the past. It encompasses the role of nature through human history in a broad social, political, economic and cultural analysis. This collection of up to 2,367 documents will be an important resource enabling the study of colonial and post-colonial environments in the twentieth century, from 1899 up to the 1990s. The early material addresses popular themes such as imperial forestry, wildlife conservation and national parks, soil conservation, tropical disease research, colonial land tenure, industrial development and agriculture. Later material is drawn from the Overseas Development departments and focuses on development aid in the context of natural resources, energy, population and public health, urbanization, pollution, warfare, human responses to natural disasters, renewable technology and climate. 

If this opportunity is of interest to you, please email us at procurement@nationalarchives.gov.uk by 5pm (UK time) on 23 November 2021.

Title: M20 Moveable Barrier Permanent Solution Stage 2 (via CCS RM6088)
Description:
The M20 Moveable Barrier Solution is a 2-stage project; inasmuch that the plan is to have two separate operational plans. The overall aim of the scheme is to provide on-road queuing capacity on the M20 coast bound carriageway between J8 and J9 for port-bound freight traffic to minimise disruption on the Kent Strategic and Local Road Networks in the event of Cross-Channel disruption.

Stage 1 delivered a solution to address potential delays caused by additional customs and immigrations checks due to legislative change associated with UK's exit from the EU in January 2021. 

Stage 2 (Phase 1) is a longer-term permanent solution to address delays arising from planned or unplanned emergency events that disrupt port traffic, such as bad weather affecting Channel crossing conditions.

Stage 2 (Phase 2) - this contract - comprises delivery of permanent highway infrastructure to enable a traffic management contra-flow operational solution to be rapidly deployed on the M20 London bound carriageway between J8 and J9 using Moveable Barriers, while port-bound freight is queued on the coast bound carriageway. There are typically 2 emergency events per year each lasting up to 5 days only. Each emergency activation is to be delivered within a 48-hour period to permit resource mobilisation and to include a 12-hour deployment period.

Title: Provision of Grounds Maintenance Services
Description:
As part of the management of the Coal Authority headquarters in Mansfield, we are looking to source a supplier to provide grounds maintenance services in accordance to the detailed requirements within the specification. 

At a minimum, services are to be provided 52 weeks a year. All services laid out within the specification are to be carried out to recognised horticultural standards and safe systems of work. 

Sustainability and Environmental management is equally important to us and the successful supplier will be expected to work with, adapt and support the Authority's developing environmental, sustainability and biodiversity approaches. As part of this the supplier will be expected to include within their response naturalistic and nature-friendly grounds maintenance methods, including reduced reliance on chemicals for weed control.

We have organised two opportunities for site visits for interested parties so that an informed tender submission can be completed.

These opportunities are on the following dates;

18 March 2022 - 1000hrs -1600hrs and

Anyone who would like to attend site should contact us to book an appointment by sending a message through our procurement portal InBye.

Title: Mental Health Training Provision
Description:
West Yorkshire Police (WYP) is the fourth largest force in the country, employing approximately 10,000 people. The 5 divisions cover Leeds, Wakefield, Bradford, Calderdale and Kirklees.
The People Directorate of West Yorkshire Police (WYP) have secured funding in order to support employee wellbeing provision during the recovery from the Covid pandemic for Police Officers and Police staff.   
WYP have a good range of interventions, support and opportunities for our people to access if they need help, but illness associated with mental ill health still accounts for the largest proportion of absence and is a high amber risk on Strategic Risk Register. The Force Management Statement return in relation to wellbeing continues to raise concerns about capacity to deal with mental health related demand and HMICFRS have inspected and measured wellbeing provisions this year.  
There are three key aims from the funding; increase knowledge and awareness of mental health issues, Increase awareness of mental health issues across the whole workforce in order to provide people with the knowledge to provide peer support to colleagues, improve prevention of mental health issues by reducing stigma and discrimination. 
The successful provider will be expected to design and deliver a twelve-month training programme to achieve the above via a blended approach. This should be based on a model of maximising participant numbers, while balancing appropriate quality and meaningfulness.

Title: Foresight Project Impact Evaluation
Description:
***THIS IS NOT A CALL FOR COMPETITION**** This contract has been awarded.

Aims and Objectives of the Project

An objective, structured evaluation of the impact of recent Foresight projects conducted in a way that provides a template for evaluating futures work going forward.

By the end of the supplier's work:
1. We have an objective evaluation of the impact of a set of past foresight projects and what actions and conditions led to this to learn from (list in scope below)

2. We have a framework through which to evaluate foresight work going forward, bringing greater consistency and efficiency to our evaluation in future

1. A clear framework for codifying the impact of foresight work, with accompanying explanation of why the supplier recommends this

2. A short guide to using this framework to evaluate - methods and approaches

3. A short report documenting the impact the listed Foresight project has had using the
framework created

Title: Informing the Future of the Past (IFP) 2022 - AWARD
Description:
The purpose of this work is to ensure guidance for Historic Environment Records (HERs) is up-to-date and easily accessible. Current guidance, also referred to as Informing the Future of the Past, is available as an online manual that uses a wiki format and is delivered via the Archaeology Data Service (https://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/ifp/).  It was published in 2012 and although the original intention was to regularly update sections, this has not taken place.
      
      The consultancy work will be based on liaison with the HER community, Heritage Information Partnership (HIPS) team and others to:
      1. Develop detailed proposals for restructuring IFP to better align with current audit practices. 
      2. Carry out research to identify different options for a new digital home for IFP 2022.
      3. Secure agreement from sector partners on a new IFP structure and digital platform.
      4. Complete a detailed timetable for re-drafting and uploading IFP content to the new digital platform.
      5. Draft a restructured IFP that incorporates existing content where appropriate.
      6. Draft updates to key sections of IFP.
      7. Research the most cost-effective and interactive approaches to training staff responsible for maintaining the HER and, in the light of these findings, develop a training plan in consultation with sector specialists.
      8. Develop a sustainable plan to keep IFP up-to-date and establish it as a live suite of resources.
Supplier [Name|Address|Ref type|Ref Numb: [Exegesis Spatial Data Management|Great House Barn, -1, LD3 0HU|NONE||No|No]

Title: DF Dependency and Recovery for South Yorkshire - Yorkshire and the Humber
Description:
The Authority has procured a Dependency and Recovery services for People on Probation due a significant proportion of
People on Probation having a dependency on legal and illegal substances and activities. The impact of this is wide-ranging both for the individual, their families and for society. Substance use disorders often cooccur alongside other mental illnesses. More than half of people with substance use disorders also have a mental illness. Frequently, each disorder amplifies the symptoms of the other. People on probation require a broad range of substance misuse and addiction related support for a range of complex needs.  These services will not duplicate existing clinical commissioned services but should enhance an individual's ability to access the clinical services and support them in this need area.  The service is for adult and young adult males.

Title: Provision of Catering Services For Galileo Multi Academy Trust
Description:
Galileo Multi Academy Trust is based in Redcar and Cleveland, serving over 3,000 children aged 2 - 11 with around 500 staff. 

The Trust is undertaking this tender process with the objective of sourcing a catering provider for 9 of the 10 primary schools within the Trust. We hope to provide a first-class catering experience to pupils, staff, and visitors, whilst ensuring the facilities are maintained to exceptional standards for all school requirements.  

The contract being tendered is to provide a healthy, high-quality, value for money catering service to all school pupils (including free school meals), staff, and a hospitality service as required.  The contract also requires the successful applicant to assist with food quality, food education, pupil interaction and communication, consistency of food and service and continual value for money.  

The contract will be for services to start on 1 September 2022.  The contract is a three-year contract with the option to extend for two years on a +1yr, +1yr basis.  More details of the opportunity and the key requirements are provided in the Invitation to Tender documents.

The opportunity is posted on the Trust website.

Title: Provision of Supported Living for People with a Learning Disability, Mental Health Problem, Autism or a Physical/Sensory Impairment
Description:
Cumbria County Council is aiming to support the provider market to develop the supported living required to meet the changing needs of the Cumbrian population.

We are seeking providers who are able to meet the eligible needs and, where appropriate, accommodation needs of citizens of Cumbria with:

1. a learning disability

2. a mental health problem

3. autism

4. a physical and/or sensory impairment.

From time to time as part of the commissioning process, the Council needs to re-contract providers of supported living. As part of these new contracts, the Council is aiming to support the provider market to develop the supported living required to meet the changing needs of the Cumbrian population.

This Framework is open which means throughout the Term additional providers may be added to the Framework Providers.

When the Council elects to re-open the Framework it will advertise the opportunity online.

This Framework Agreement is for use by the following Contracting Authorities that exist on 08/02/2022 Notice Number 2022/S 000-003665 and any successor council as defined in The Local Government (Structural Changes) (Transfer of Functions, Property, Rights and Liabilities) Regulations 2008 to the following Contracting Authorities:

Cumbria County Council

Cumberland Council

Title: The Collection & Boarding of Banned Breeds, Dangerous & Seized Dogs for South Yorkshire Police
Description:
South Yorkshire Police (SYP) have awarded a contract for a 24 hour, 7 day, 365(6) days a year dog collection and boarding service provision of 35 kennels, with the potential for access to further kennels should the need arise.

Following a call from SYP, the successful Service Provider will collect the dog(s) urgently within the minimum timescale possible and within a maximum of 90 minutes following notification. 

The successful Service Provider will safely remove the dog(s) without the assistance of the attending police officer as they may not be equipped or experienced in dog handling.  The dogs that are to be collected can range from the very friendly to those that can be very difficult and dangerous to handle.  

The successful Service Provider will kennel the dog(s) for a duration which will be determined by SYP.  The duration of kennelling the dog(s) could be long-term.  The successful Service Provider will provide adequate and secure shelter, food and healthcare sufficient to meet the needs of the animal in line with the animal welfare act for animals placed in the custody of the kennel.  Any specific healthcare requirements for a dog(s) will be agreed between the Service Provider and SYP following veterinary consultation.

The contract is for an initial period of 4 years, with the option to extend by a further 2 x 12-month periods.

Title: Short Term Services - Live In Care Services
Description:
HCC published a call-off from the Help to Live at Home Open framework. 
 
A call-off for the Live-In Care service was undertaken through in-tend (reference AS18630) from 15 March to 30 March 2022.  There was no restriction on how many lots one provider could be awarded.  However no provider scored above the minimum 50% quality requirement. 

The Live-in Care service will be delivered Countywide across Hampshire based on four Lots, primarily linked to an Integrated Care Systems (ICS) and hospital systems. However, referrals may come from any of the Hospitals within the Hampshire or outlying system or maybe a community referral. All referrals will be made to providers from the Council's Hospital Operational Teams or a Community Team with prior agreement by the Hospital team. 

The commissioner has liaised with the current incumbent of this service and in order to maintain a seamless service, the Authority will direct award under regulation 32.

Title: Provision of a Buckinghamshire Demand Responsive Bus Service
Description:
Buckinghamshire Council wish to commission a Demand Responsive Transport Service for Buckinghamshire. The service provision will be divided into 2 lots - one for Aylesbury and one for High Wycombe. Organisations can tender for one or both lots.

LOT 1 - Aylesbury
The scheme for Aylesbury focuses on improving connectivity to the rural areas surrounding Aylesbury (Weedon, Hartwell, Aston Clinton, Weston Turville and Halton) which are currently under-served by traditional bus routes. The DRT service will provide better connections to local economic, retail, education, and healthcare facilities, notably Stoke Mandeville Hospital (SMH) which is an important local employer and a key regional hospital. 

The budget for this service is Â£1,700,000 for the full contract term.

LOT 2 - High Wycombe
The scheme for High Wycombe focuses on improving connectivity to the rural areas surrounding High Wycombe (Booker, Downley, and Wooburn Green). These areas are currently under-served by traditional bus routes so implementing a DRT service will provide better connections to local economic, retail, education and healthcare facilities, notably the Cressex Industrial Park which is a key source of employment in the area, town centre, railway station and hospital.
The budget for this service is Â£2,600,000 for the full contract term.

The contract start date for both services is Wednesday 1st June 2022. The contract term is 3 years with the option to extend for two further 12 month periods.

If your organisation wishes to participate in this process, you need to register with the Buckinghamshire Business Portal.  You will be unable to take part if you do not register. Please use the link below and follow the instructions on the website:

www.supplybucksbusiness.org.uk
 
Tenders must be returned via the Buckinghamshire Business Portal. The tender return date is midday on Tuesday 11th January 2022. Tenders received after this time and date will not be accepted.

Description:

Road markings materials and performance shall be in accordance with BS EN 1436:2018., BS EN 1871:2020 and BS EN 1463-1:2009.  It is expected that any new standards implemented post contract award shall be adhered to by the awarded contractor.

Road markings shall be laid in accordance with the Traffic Signs Regulations and General Directions 2016, unless specified otherwise. Road markings on principal and other classified roads should have a life expectancy of three years. Road markings shall be replaced on a cyclical basis as instructed by Salford City Council, working within the network priorities.

Title: Trade Flow Data Provision requirements for AHDB
Description:
AWARD OF CONTRACT - AHDB requires information on trade flows between different countries across the globe. At the most granular level, this "Dataset" includes:

-	Trade flows from two- down to ten-digit HS commodity code level. 
-	Trade flow information for a variety of countries across the globe (both reporter and/or partner country).
-	Information on the direction of travel (import, export, total trade, and trade balance).
-	Information on the port and mode of transport where possible
-	Information on the State where applicable. 
-	The volume of any trade flow depicted in appropriate units (e.g. kilograms, tonnes, head or litres). 
-	The value of any trade flow in Â£s, USDs, â¬s and the reporting country's own currency.
-	The average unit price of trade flows. 
-	The latest monthly information as well as historical monthly, quarterly, and annual data (at least 20 years).

Title: Alleyways Refurbishment Programme - Civils Contractor
Description:
1.1	Liverpool Streetscene Services Limited (LSSL) is a wholly owned subsidiary of Liverpool City Council (LCC) and in March 2016 was formed to deliver several essential services across the city of Liverpool including refuse and recycling, street cleansing and parks, cemeteries and grounds maintenance. The company has an estimated annual turnover of around Â£30 million.
Liverpool has approximately 22,000 properties built adjacent to a 4ft (foot) wide alleyway which receive a weekly collection of bagged domestic waste from the rear alleyway. A further 38,000 terraced properties are located adjacent to a 9ft wide alleyways.
Since 2018 the LCC/LSSL have led a programme to not only improve the alleyway infrastructure making it safer for both residents and staff, but also to introduce alternative waste collection methods in those areas with 4ft alleyways. The improvements in infrastructure and changes to using communal street collections have led to an improvement in conditions for the residents who live in these areas and contribute to them becoming thriving neighbourhoods.
Prospective suppliers are invited to submit proposals for this contract to provide civil engineering works for the refurbishment of Alleyways as per specifications.
The contract is expected to commence on the date provided in the Contract Data.

Title: Provision of Leadership Development Training Services
Description:
***THIS OPPORTUNITY IS CLOSED. THIS IS A CONTRACT AWARD NOTICE***

The purpose of the Financial Reporting Council (FRC) is to serve the public interest by setting high standards of corporate governance, reporting and audit and by holding to account those responsible for delivering them.
Delivering on our purpose will bring a variety of benefits. Improved outcomes, created by each of our regulatory activities are shown in the circle; each of which can positively reinforce others in the circle and contribute to overall benefits for a wide range of stakeholders such as greater transparency, increased trust in UK markets and a lower cost of capital for companies. Our direct stakeholders include companies, institutional investors, auditors, actuaries, accountants and their respective professional bodies. Our indirect stakeholders include retail shareholders, suppliers, employees, customers, communities, pensioners and savers, and financial institutions, all of whom have an interest in the health of companies and other organisations within our existing and future regulatory scope and in the success of the UK corporate sector as a whole.

The FRC had a requirement for Leadership Training Services. We required a structured programme of leadership development, specifically for newly appointed and emerging leaders (for use when existing public sector provisions do not fully address our requirements).

The aim of the leadership development is for the FRC delegate to develop advanced skills that are needed for them to take on more senior position within FRC.
We expect the programme(s) to be: -
â¢	Established with a track record of successful learning outcomes
â¢	Commitment to cross sector diversity
â¢	Specifically aimed newly appointed and emerging leaders
â¢	Relevant and Focused (on key leadership challenges and skills required)
â¢	Option of residential / online with mixed delegate groups (i.e. not just FRC delegates)


Please see attached ITT for further information.

Title: Heat Pump Ready: Stream 3 - Trial Support and Learning
Description:
Improving Heat Pump Ready project and programme delivery through: 

-The capture and sharing of progress, evidence, knowledge, and lessons between Stream 1 projects during Phase 2 of project delivery 
-Establishing and coordinating interactions between Stream 1 projects and special interest working groups in support of areas of common delivery 
-Brokering relationships between Stream 1 projects and the solutions being developed in Stream 2 and other innovation programmes 


Incentivising actions among key heat pump stakeholders that advance the heat pump sector and contribute to increases in heat pump deployments, including as part of high-density, localised deployments, through: 

-Developing and maintaining an understanding of stakeholder evidence and knowledge requirements, including the barriers that prevent actions taking place; 
-Using this understanding of evidence needs to develop tailored knowledge, dissemination and other guidance products that demonstrate the feasibility of heat pump installations and the overcoming of known barriers, and disseminating these products amongst key stakeholders.

Title: Herne Relief Road (SC21059)
Description:
The aim of the Herne Relief Road is to alleviate existing traffic congestion concerns through the historic village of Herne. The village of Herne is subject to an existing Air Quality Management Area. The scheme aims to provide an alternative route to the existing constrained A291 and therefore reduce congestion and improve journey time reliability through the vicinity of Herne and support the construction of approximately 3,000 homes. The project also addressed the concerns of local residents, in regard to the safety of the current junctions between Bullockstone Road and A291 Canterbury Road and Bullockstone Road and Lower Herne Road. 

The Relief Road takes the form of a widened Bullockstone Road, currently a minor country lane that connects the village of Greenhill and the old Thanet Way with the A291 Canterbury Road. This includes new roundabout junctions to upgrade the existing priority junction between A291 Canterbury Road and Bullockstone Road and the creation of a new junction between the Strode Farm Development Spine Road and Bullockstone Road. Bullockstone Road is to be widened to a 7m carriageway between these two junctions. The works also include the provision of a new pedestrian/cycling facility along the full extent of Bullockstone Road. The Relief Road, in combination with a Spine Road through the Strode Farm Housing development, aims to provide an alternative route for strategic traffic between A299 and Canterbury, avoiding historic Herne village.

The project is funded by developer contributions from three nearby housing developments (Strode Farm, Lower Herne Golf Club and Hillborough). Kent County Council have also secured Â£2.1m from the Growing Places Fund to help forward fund the scheme. 

The extent of the works included within the scope of this contract extend from the junction between the A291 Canterbury Road and Bullockstone Road to the junction between Lower Herne Road and Bullockstone Road. The work extent includes the construction of two highway drainage attenuation ponds, one to the north of Lower Herne Road and one to the west of Bullockstone Road, to the south of Hares Wood. The carriageway widening will impact Bullockstone Hill Wood, which borders the road to the east at the northern extent of the works. Bullockstone Hill Wood has designated Ancient Woodland status. 

KCC are supporting Canterbury City Council and are responsible for the design and delivery of the project. The scheme is split into two phases and thus the anticipated construction period will be circa 70 weeks and the anticipated construction costs are circa Â£5m.

Further information about the scheme can be found at the following link on the Kent County Council Website: 
 
https://www.kent.gov.uk/roads-and-travel/road-projects/planned-road-projects/bullockstone-road-improvement-scheme

Title: Harness GP Access Hub (Brent)
Description:
A contract has been awarded to Harness Care Ltd as per the notice issued on 29th March 2022 (CF-0731100D0O000000rwimUAA1). The intention is for the service provision to transition to nationally specified Network DES Commissioning (GMS core) beyond September, which will lead to an integrated combined access offer as an integral part of the PCN Network Contract DES delivered to 100% of the population it serves. The new contract is required to ensures service continuity.

NHS North West London requires the provision of after-hour service. This service must be delivered by a group of GP providers to all patients registered with their constituent practices, ensuring equity of access and quality of service provision to the entire population group. Where there is more than one group of GP providers within the geographical boundaries of the respective CCG, the groups may operate collectively. The GP provider grouping and location(s) of delivery of the service (number of delivery points) will need to be agreed with the commissioning CCG.

NHS North West London is commissioning an Extended Hours Service (EHS) that supports its strategic commissioning intentions for:
- Improving patient access to high-quality urgent and routine primary care.
- Improving the patient experience of primary care.
- Promoting the appropriate use of urgent and routine primary care services through the redirection of patients to the right service for their health needs.

The aims of this service will be achieved through the provision of Extended Hours delivery points or 'hubs' by way of providing additional opening hours in Primary Care.

Title: DDaT21551 - URKI Identity & Access Management
Description:
Aims
IAM Project Vision
The vision for the UKRI IAM Project is 'to deliver a modern intelligent identity and access management platform which provides Identity Governance and Administration (IGA) and Access Management (AM) services that encompass the entire organisation.'

To achieve the vision, the project will focus on delivering the following benefits: 
â¢	Reduced Risk
â¢	Reduced Operational Costs
â¢	Improved User Experience
â¢	Improved Efficiency 

Objectives
The objective of UKRI IAM Project is to deliver the strategic Identity Access Management (IAM) capabilities. To avoid ambiguity, the industry standard terminology is used to describe Identity Governance and Administration (IGA) and Access Management (AM) capabilities. The low-level requirements can be found in the "IAM Technical Compliance Requirements":

Please ensure you review all attached information to ensure a full understanding of this requirement. All attachments can be found with the Document Uploads tab within the Delta eSourcing Portal. 

This contract will be awarded based on the evaluation criteria as set out in the RFP document. 

How to Apply
UK Shared Business Services Ltd (UK SBS) will be using the Delta eSourcing Portal for this procurement. 

To register on the Delta eSourcing portal please use the link https://www.delta-esourcing.com/ and follow the instructions to register.

If you are already registered on the Delta eSourcing Portal and wish to participate in this procurement, please use the link: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/ and the follow the instructions to 'Log in' 

Once you are logged into the system you will be able to link yourself into this procurement using the Access Code: 5DJDP8WMVM

The contract shall be in operation for an initial period of 2 years with the option to extend +1 +1 + 1, for a total of 5 years.

DO NOT APPLY DIRECTLY TO BUYER

Responses must be received by the date and time in the tender documentation; responses received outside of the deadline or not sent via the Delta eSourcing portal will not be accepted or considered by the Contracting Authority further for this opportunity. If the Contracting Authority decides to enter into a contract with any successful organisation(s), this does not mean that there is any guarantee of subsequent contracts being awarded. About UK Shared Business Services 

UK Shared Business Services Ltd (UK SBS) brings a commercial attitude to the public sector; helping our contracting authorities to improve efficiency, generate savings and modernise.

Where UK SBS is not named as the Contracting Authority within the documentation, UK SBS will be acting as an agent on behalf of the Contracting Authority.

Our broad range of expert services is shared by our customers. This allows our customers the freedom to focus resources on core activities; innovating and transforming their own organisations.

Description:
The overall objective of the Hydrogen BECCS Innovation Programme is to support development of technologies which will enable the commercialisation and deployment of Hydrogen BECCS at scale to achieve negative emission and hydrogen production targets.

A two-Phase Small Business Research Initiative (SBRI) pre-commercial procurement process will be used to deliver this competition. Phase 1 (total budget Â£5m) will support multiple projects to scope and develop a feasible prototype demonstration project to be run in Phase 2. Phase 2 takes the most promising projects from Phase 1 and supports the proposed physical demonstration of their innovation.

This notice is for Phase 1 and contains the information for 13 out of 22 SBRI Contracts.

Title: Tender for the Supply and Installation of a Sintering System for the Production of Ndfeb Magnets
Description:
The University of Birmingham invites tenders for supply of a sintering system for the production of sintered NdFeB permanent magnets. The proposed unit will allow inert charging and sintering of a batch size of a minimum of 50 kg of NdFeB under vacuum or inert atmosphere.

Note, due to space requirements of the system, the proposed sintering system will be installed at Tyesley Energy Park in Birmingham.

This project is funded by the UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) Industrial Strategy Challenge Fund; Driving the Electric Revolution.

General characteristics
A sintering furnace for NdFeB with a minimum capacity of 50 kg per batch. The system must incorporate inert loading of pressed NdFeB compacts.
The equipment must comply with all the relevant UK law, regulations, and British Standards.

Specification
i. Requirements
1) The complete system must be capable of the handling of batch sizes of a minimum of 50 kg, nominally for rectangular magnet blocks with dimensions up to 40mm x 40mm x 20mm.
2) The system should allow for inert loading of pressed compacts by use of a glove box system. 
3) The system needs to be ergonomically designed for the efficient handling of the material, facilitating the inert handling and transfer of green compacts (maximum oxygen content 20 ppm) also allowing for the easy transfer in and out of sintering trays.
4) The sintering vessel should be capable of being pumped down to a vacuum level of 10-4 mBar, with appropriate filters / traps to avoid powder entering the vacuum pump.
5) The sintering furnace must be capable of consistently achieving temperatures up to a minimum of 1200Â°C under vacuum or inert gas with good thermal uniformity (in the order of +/-5Â°C) during the ramp and sintering stages.
6) During the sintering process hydrogen will be evolved from the compacts (up to 900Â°C). The pumping system must be capable of safely removing this hydrogen.
The sintering system needs to have the ability to actively cool the material from the sintering temperature at a controlled rate. Appropriate control should be incorporated with the ability to log the process parameters. Temp, Vacuum, oxygen levels, moisture levels, flow rates, power consumption. Ability to set multiple programmes for gas control and temp profiles through PID control. 
ii. Optional Component Technologies
7) The system could incorporate two solvent extraction chambers and pumping systems to remove solvents from the green compacts prior to the sintering process

All correspondence should go via the University's In-Tend website. 
Your tender documents and information must be submitted via In-Tend by the date and time specified; www.in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofbirmingham/aspx/Home
(https://www.in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofbirmingham/aspx/Home)

Title: BHCC HP 032295  - 249 Elm Grove & 240 Freshfield Road Full Survey & Scope
Description:
The survey is to include investigation and appraisal of all visible and accessible parts of the buildings, including intrusive investigations to establish condition of wall ties & cavity wall insulation and those areas which are not part of the structure, such as drainage runs & incoming services.

If access equipment or intrusive survey is required to reasonably assess condition, then this should be discussed and planned with the Contracting Authority and arranged via the Contracting Authority and its construction partners.

Any immediate risks identified must be reported to the Contracting Authority in writing at the time of the survey.

The building and building related elements to be investigated and appraised for inclusion in the report are:
i)	All external building elements. This includes, but is not limited to, roof coverings/structure,    wall structure/finishes including cavity wall ties, chimneys, flues, concrete frame, rainwater goods, fascias & soffits, windows, lintels, balconies, doors, lightning protection, external details/features, canopies, stores.
ii)	Analysis and appraisal of existing u-values through building fabric, and key elements (e.g. windows/roof/floor/ different wall types). Options for replacement and/or improvement should be set out clearly, with costs against each, and recommendations for future reasonable repairs and/or improvement. 
iii)	Note clearly any and all instances of damp, water ingress or condensation, and the likely cause, and options for remedial repairs.
viii)	In all areas and elements, any Fire, asbestos or other health and safety risks.

Organisation Name: North West London Clinical Commissioning Group
Title: Brent Enhanced Services Offer - Kilburn
Description:
To ensure continuity of the service, a short term contract has been awarded to Kilburn Primary Care Co-op Limited whilst undergoing a procurement exercise for the service. Market Engagement has been undertaken in advance.

NWL CCG required the provision of various Enhanced Primary Care Services covering the total registered population across multiple GP and PCN sites.

The contracts have been designed to deliver a range of enhanced primary care services via 347 GP practices and/or GP federations in each of the 8 boroughs in North West London. Full patient population coverage is central to improving local care and reducing variability in people's outcomes so that every patient has access to the range of services offered. Specifications within the contracts are for out-of-hospital services including services such as phlebotomy, ECG, and diabetes and are outcomes-based.

The contracts have been designed to focus on improving clinical outcomes, driving improvements in the consistency of care provision in all GP practices, reducing unwarranted variation in general practice, and reducing health and care inequalities.
The contracts are delivered in general practices and at scale by PCNs/other GP-led organisations to enable providers to deliver the full range of services covered by the contracts and full patient population coverage.

Organisation Name: North West London Clinical Commissioning Group
Title: WSIC - Kilburn
Description:
To ensure continuity of the service, a short-term contract (12 months) has been awarded to Kilburn Primary Care Co-op Limited whilst undergoing a procurement exercise for the service. Market Engagement has been undertaken in advance.

One of the main focus areas is to dissolve the divide between primary and community + secondary based health services, delivering new service models in which patients get more options, better support, and joined-up care at the right time in the optimal place, through Primary Care Networks (PCNs).

The service will provide high-quality of care and improve people's experience by:

- Providing holistic, person-centred care, rooted in individual needs, goals and aspirations rather than solely 'treating the symptoms'. The emphasis is on diagnosis care planning and proactive care + care for dying, health education, and reaching out to health inequalities vulnerable groups and other non-aligned disadvantaged people.
- Support early identification and intervention through population health management.
- Supporting people to live independently in their own homes and minimising the amount of time they spend in hospital.
- Coordinate the care of individual patients and work collaboratively with the patients, their family, GPs, services in the community, local authorities and voluntary services.
- Provide expertise and support for GPs, community services and other service providers.
- To improve the provision of coordinated care and to reduce NEL admissions and A&E. attendances where appropriate.
- To get NEL admission services to identify their Cost and manage patients appropriately.
- To improve access to diagnostic facilities by GPs thereby reducing the demand for unnecessary outpatient services.
- To increase virtual consultation rates by primary and secondary care.
- To increase self-care by individuals.
- To disencumber unnecessary processes.
- To recognise diagnostic uncertainty by clinicians.
- To provide meaningful support to patient-facing teams by realignment of office-based personnel.
- To mandate office-based roles have to incorporate at least 1 day a month in patient-facing direct contact services within their job plans.

Notice Identifier: 703094450 (DInfoCom/0200) - Crimes Data Unit (SPCB) -DocStor Support and Maintenance Renewal
Title: 703094450 (DInfoCom/0200) - Crimes Data Unit (SPCB) -DocStor Support and Maintenance Renewal
Description:
Provision of DocStor support and maintenance renewal, used by the Service Police Crime Bureau (SPCB), Application Support Team (AST) The purpose of renewing this product is to afford the Service Police and wider Service Justice System (SJS) with the ability to manage, store and retrieve all documentation and recorded investigative material for its future disclosure and presentation in court proceedings, judicial reviews and appeals.
Army Headquarters is responsible for overseeing all non-MODNET ICS procurements for the Army.
The SPCB, Application Support Team (AST) on behalf of the Service Police are responsible for managing and maintaining the Service Police's IT systems and services. These services are vital to the continuity of uninterrupted military policing capability and operational effectiveness worldwide.
SPCB utilises a locally networked onsite document archive server, storage array, and microfiche scanning and upload and deletion tool, collectively known as Replacement Archive Management System (RAMS), provided by DocStor. This provides the Service Police and wider Service Justice System with an electronic documentation management, storage and retrieval system for all recorded investigative material.

Organisation Name: North West London Clinical Commissioning Group
Title: Brent GP Extended Access Hub Service
Description:
A contract has been awarded to Kilburn Park Medical Centre as per the notice issued on 29th March 2022 (CF-0731100D0O000000rwimUAA1). The intention is for the service provision to transition to nationally specified Network DES Commissioning (GMS core) beyond September, which will lead to an integrated combined access offer as an integral part of the PCN Network Contract DES delivered to 100% of the population it serves. The new contract is required to ensures service continuity.

NWL CCG requires the provision of after-hour service. This service must be delivered by a group of GP providers to all patients registered with their constituent practices, ensuring equity of access and quality of service provision to the entire population group. Where there is more than one group of GP providers within the geographical boundaries of the respective CCG, the groups may operate collectively. The GP provider grouping and location(s) of delivery of the service (number of delivery points) will need to be agreed with the commissioning CCG.

The CCG is commissioning an Extended Hours Service (EHS) that supports its strategic commissioning intentions for:
- Improving patient access to high-quality urgent and routine primary care.
- Improving the patient experience of primary care.
- Promoting the appropriate use of urgent and routine primary care services through the redirection of patients to the right service for their health needs.

The aims of this service will be achieved through the provision of Extended Hours delivery points or 'hubs' by way of providing additional opening hours in Primary Care.

Title: Provision of Medicine Supply Services
Description:
Nottinghamshire Healthcare holds main contracts with NHS England for the delivery of healthcare in a number of prison establishments. The Forensic Division is also responsible for Wathwood Hospital which is a 76 bedded medium secure unit belonging to Nottinghamshire Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust. It is located at Wath-upon-Dearne to the north of Rotherham and caters for individuals who require assessment and treatment of mental health difficulties in a secure environment

The purpose of this project is to engage a professional pharmacy provider to deliver a pharmacy medicines supply service that is safe, patient-centred, efficient, cost effective and complies with relevant statutory requirements.

Title: Awarded for Online Roadworks Approval Software
Description:
The Roadworks Performance project is looking for a 12 month trial to evidence improvements to both journey times across London's busiest routes and deliver operational efficiencies by restructuring processes for agreeing work proposals where bus services are impacted. The trial will be focussed on London's core bus network across a maximum of six London boroughs. Underpinning the trial will be the need to develop new software functionality to facilitate the delivery of data-led and faster agreements on work proposals that have an impact on bus journeys. Central to achieving these outcomes requires a collaborative stakeholder approach involving representatives from London Boroughs, utility work promoters and TFL's Bus and Network Management directorates.
The contract is for the online applications for bus stop suspension and diversion requests for TFL's approval. The software provides full end-to-end workflow process between the applicant and authority.

Title: Provision of a New Antimicrobial to the NHS in England
Description:
This procurement was conducted by NHS England. The contract entered into pursuant to this procurement is between the successful supplier Shionogi and NHS England (formerly the National Health Service Commissioning Board).

Organisations wishing to participate in this procurement had to have at least one EU licensed antimicrobial that would have a UK launch dated on or between 1 January 2020 and 31 December 2020 and that was active against one or more pathogens on the World Health Organisation priority pathogen list.

There was no limit on the number of antimicrobials that an organisation could offer.

The Contract awarded pursuant to the procurement are for use by the Department of Health and Social Care, Public Health England, the NHS in England and by private sector healthcare contractors and agents working on behalf of the aforementioned.

Shionogi will be responsible for supply of the selected antimicrobial from 1 July 2022.

The duration of the contract awarded will be for an initial period of three (3) years, with the option to extend (by mutual agreement) for an additional period or periods up to seven (7) years.

Further information was set out in the procurement documents which are available to download from the NICE website https://www.nice.org.uk/about/what-we-do/life-sciences/scientific-advice/models-for-the-evaluation-and-purchase-of-antimicrobials

Note that the contract value stated (Â£100 million) is not the exact contract value, as this cannot be published for reasons of confidentiality / damage to commercial interests.
However, the contract value is broadly commensurate with the advertised value of Â£100million

Title: CEFAS22-11 Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) Services Framework
Description:
To help meet increasing needs, Cefas have a requirement to establish a new framework agreement for the provision of Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) services to include the approaches detailed below, and any proposed solution/awarded Provider must be able to fulfil the following requirements (as a minimum):

1. The service provided must include the receipt of sample(s) from Cefas, Library Preparation, Quality Control and sequencing, and delivery of data back to Cefas.

2. The service provided must be able to offer, depending on the requirements of the project, a range of NGS technical options including but not restricted to high throughput short and long read sequencing (including Illumina MiSeq, HiSeq, and NovaSeq platforms, PacBio, and Oxford Nanopore Technologies) for a diverse range of sequencing requirements, including but not restricted to amplicon sequencing (metabarcoding and multiplexed protocols), whole/partial genome sequencing, mitogenomics, genome skimming, metagenomics and metatranscriptomics, RNASeq, and hybrid approaches.

Depending on the requirements of the project, some processing and initial analyses of the raw data may be requested. Collaborative, jointly-authored projects will also be undertaken, with input from both parties.

Title: Public Sector Decarbonisation Scheme Surveys for Defra
Description:
Carry out decarbonisation surveys for Defra across 22 sites to ensure an application is submitted in time for PSDS 3b 
The primary objective is to identify projects that are eligible for the PSDS scheme. However, we will carry out the low carbon surveys to fit into Defra's wider
decarbonisation strategy. Any identified measures deemed ineligible for PSDS will still be captured and presented to Defra to support the wider strategy. The activities carried out as part of this project would include:
1) Energy and asset data collation and review
2) On site surveys assessing opportunities for heat decarbonisation, energy efficiency and renewable energy
3) Project management including update meetings, coordination of site visits and data management
4) Associated analysis, calculations and estimations of energy, cost and carbon savings
5) Completion of PSDS application templates
6) Supporting narrative required for the application
7) High level schematics indicating locations of retrofit measures
8) A formal recommendations report and presentation
9) A technology register of all decarbonisation measures identified

Title: Framework Agreement for Mental Health, Self-Harm and Suicide Prevention Training
Description:
Nottinghamshire County Council conducted an open tender procedure and as a result have appointed a single Provider to deliver accredited and non-accredited Mental Health, Self-Harm and Suicide Prevention Training to a range of audiences, under a Framework Agreement.\r
\r
Under the Framework Agreement the Provider may meet the training requirements of the following 'Commissioners':\r
â¢ Nottinghamshire County Council (the 'Lead Commissioner')\r
â¢ Nottingham City Council\r
â¢ Nottingham and Nottinghamshire Clinical Commissioning Group (CCG) which, during the term of this Framework Agreement, is likely to be replaced by Nottingham and Nottinghamshire Integrated Care Board (ICB) - subject to the approval of the Health and Care Bill which is currently going through Parliament. The changes proposed in the Health and Care Bill also include expansion of the boundary defined by the current Nottingham and Nottinghamshire CCG to take in Bassetlaw. For the avoidance of doubt, from the point at which the Nottingham and Nottinghamshire ICB is established this Framework Agreement will be accessible to all Commissioners within its newly established geographical boundaries.\r
\r
The volume and type of training that will be the subject of 'Call-Off' contracts under the Framework Agreement will be informed by the outcome of a Training Needs Analysis which has been commissioned separately from the Framework Agreement by the Lead Commissioner, Nottinghamshire County Council and is due to report in April 2022.\r
\r
The estimated maximum total contract value for Call-Off's commissioned under this Framework Agreement is Â£1,500,000 over the term of 4 years. However, there is no guaranteed volume or value for the provision of Training Services through this Framework Agreement and the Commissioners included in the scope of the Framework Agreement may choose not to engage with the Provider appointed under it at any point during its term.

Title: Inpatient Detoxification Service
Description:
Nottinghamshire County Council wish to appoint an experienced Provider of medically managed Inpatient Detoxification Services on behalf of the following local authorities comprising the East Midlands Consortium:-
â¢ Derbyshire County Council
â¢ Derby City Council
â¢ Leicester City Council
â¢ Leicestershire County Council
â¢ Rutland County Council
â¢ Lincolnshire County Council
â¢ Nottingham City Council
â¢ Nottinghamshire County Council

This is a requirement for a Provider with a minimum of three years of experience of delivering medically managed Inpatient Detoxification Services that achieve positive outcomes for the people accessing the service.

The Provider is required to provide the residential facility and the withdrawal and stabilisation services. The residential facility must be within one of the local authority areas represented by the East Midlands Consortium.

The Provider will also be required to administer the service which will include co-ordination and monitoring of the referrals into the service with the aim of ensuring the allocation of bed days in the service is relative to the funding allocation for each authority.

Assuming the earliest commencement date of the 4th July 2022 the initial term of the contract will be 2 years and approximately 9 months (until 31st March 2025) with the potential to extend for up to an additional 36 months (until 31st March 2028) in increments of up to 12 months. Title: (NU/1589-64) Production of a suite of promotional videos for VOICE at the UK National Innovation Centre for Ageing
Description:
VOICE was established by Newcastle University to capture the vast experience and mental capital of the public. The digital platform was launched in Autumn 2016, and has revolutionised the ways in which members of the public can contribute their experience, ideas, insights and vision to benefit research and innovation, especially around ageing and demographic change.
The team are currently re-developing the VOICE digital infrastructure with a launch date for the new platform scheduled for September 2022.  To ensure an impactful launch, we would like to commission a suite of promotional video content, aimed at a public audience, showcasing the work of VOICE and VOICE members.
We're keen to promote the impact our members have had on the many research and innovation projects managed through VOICE, as well as promoting the breadth of activity types members can get involved in.  To do this effectively we have identified a number of case studies which would be great subjects for professional and promotional case study videos.  Outputs for each case study should include;
o	A 1-2 minute promotional video
o	A series of shorter 'taster' videos for use on social media (Facebook, Twitter & Instagram)
o	Re-designed, standardised, intro & outro titles and design elements throughout.

Submissions should be based on the 7 case studies and 4 thematic films.

Title: PAUSE Dorset
Description:
Public Health Dorset are commissioning a delivery organisation to set-up a Pause Practice and deliver the Pause programme. Pause is a licensed programme that is delivered using a social franchising approach. This means that while the programme is delivered by a local delivery organisation it will look, feel and be branded the same as other Pause Practice's in the network.  

Pause is an evidenced based national programme for women who have experienced, and are at risk of experiencing, repeat removals of children from their care. The programme aims to give women the chance to pause and take control of their lives. 

The aim of the Pause service is to give women an opportunity and support to 'pause' and take control over their lives, to improve their wellbeing, resilience and stability. This helps them set in place strong foundations on which they can build a more positive future for themselves. 

The service will contribute to a reduction in future numbers of infants brought into care and the disruption of trans-generational cycles of poor outcomes experienced by some of the most vulnerable families in our community.

Women who experience repeat removals often have complex needs which are not currently being addressed.  They experience trauma and grief associated with the removal of their children, they may suffer from domestic abuse, mental health illnesses or substance misuse and they may have built up a mistrust towards children's social care services, resulting in poor engagement with existing support services.  

Tenders are welcome from:
1. Delivery partner - either a single provider model or a lead provider model (partners who wish to collaborate together for the provision of this service, where the contract is between the commissioner and the lead provider).
2. Social outcomes partnerships - a provider organisation(s) may seek to source and work with a social outcomes partnership/investment bond funding provider.

Organisation Name: NHS SOUTH, CENTRAL AND WEST COMMISSIONING SUPPORT UNIT
Title: Integrated Healthcare Services to Thames Valley Prisons for NHS England and NHS Improvement South East
Description:
NHS England and NHS Improvement South East (NHSE/I) is seeking to commission integrated healthcare services for prisons across the Thames Valley region. NHSE/I are seeking to secure Prime Provider(s) who have the capability and capacity to deliver services in line with the specified requirements. 

There are a total of 5 establishments within the Thames Valley region, with the procurement split across 3 lots as follows (maximum total contract values shown in brackets):

â¢	Lot 1 - HMP Huntercombe, HMP Grendon & HMP Springhill (Â£31.6m)
â¢	Lot 2 - HMP Bullingdon (Â£59.6m)
â¢	Lot 3 - HMYOI Aylesbury (Â£17.5m)


The maximum whole life combined contract value available for all lots is Â£120,112,205, over a contract duration of 7 (seven years). Contracts are due to commence on 1st October 2022. 

The integrated service will include the following delivery areas: 
 
â¢	Primary healthcare (GP and nursing) 
â¢	Mental health and wellbeing 
â¢	Integrated substance misuse 
â¢	Learning disability/neurodiversity 
â¢	Pharmacy 
â¢	Social care 
â¢	Long term conditions 
â¢	Dentistry 
â¢	Optometry and audiology 
â¢	End of life care 
â¢	Sexual health 
â¢	Health promotion 
â¢	Screening and immunisations 
â¢	Therapies (pain management/physio/podiatry etc.) 
â¢	Statutory advocacy provision (IMCA and Care Act) 

Interested providers are directed to the specification(s) and supporting documentation provided with this opportunity for full details of the commissioning objectives and service requirements.

There is a separate integrated health and wellbeing services specification for each prison within each lot. 

In addition, the following national specifications are included:
â¢	Primary care services
â¢	Mental health services
â¢	Substance misuse services
â¢	Dental services
â¢	Public Health Services

There is a national prison expansion programme taking place to increase the number of available places in prison, and it is anticipated that there will be operational capacity changes across the South East prison estate.  

The contract envelope is based on current operational capacity figures and the successful provider(s) will be required to work with commissioners to address any changes that happen.

This, along with other changes resulting from reconfiguration, e.g. flow of people, resettlement and trainer populations, and aging populations, will need to be accounted for in the delivery of healthcare services. 

Changes to prison population(s) will be managed through the normal contract variation processes.

This procurement is being carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of the Commissioners.
Additional Text:
Interested providers will be able to view this notice via the 'current tenders' list on the e-procurement system In-Tend, available on the following link: https://in-tendhost.co.uk/scwcsu/aspx/Home 

In order to submit a bid, you will need to be registered on the e-procurement system and 'express an interest', and then complete a response as specified within the procurement documents. 

On registration, please include at least two contacts to allow for access to the system in times of absence.

The services are healthcare services falling within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations"), which are not subject to the full regime of the Regulations, but are instead governed by the "Light Touch Regime" contained within Chapter 3, Section 7 of the Regulations (Regulations 74 to 77).
The tendering process will be conducted in accordance with the requirements and flexibilities provided by Articles 74 to 76 of the Directive, and Regulations 74 to 76 of the Regulations. The Authority will run a transparent tender process, treating all Bidders equally. For the avoidance of doubt, the Authority will not be bound by the Regulations or the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union or any other regulations or legislation except for the specific parts or circumstances that apply to the procurement of these Services. 
  
Neither the inclusion of a Bidder selection stage, nor the use of any language or terms found in the Directive or Regulations, nor the description of the procedure voluntarily adopted by the Authority ("Open", "Restricted", "Competitive Procedure with Negotiation", "Competitive Dialogue" or any other description), nor any other indication, shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound by the Directive or Regulations, save by the provisions applicable to services coming within the scope of Annex XIV of the Directive / Schedule 3 of the Regulations. 

The Contracting Authority intends to voluntarily observe the award decision notices provisions and 10 day standstill period described in Regulation 86 of the Regulations. Unsuccessful Bidders will receive scores and reasons for the decision, including the characteristics and relative advantages of the winning bid and the reasons why the Bidder/application was unsuccessful. Deadline for lodging of appeals should be in accordance with Regulation 87 and Regulation 91 of the Regulations.

Title: Product Survey of Cat Food for Mycotoxins
Description:
The Food Standards Agency (FSA) and Food Standards Scotland (FSS) wish to develop an evidence base for current mycotoxin occurrence data within wet and dry cat food products. Particularly the Group A trichothecenes which may have increased toxic effects for cats but also to include a wide range of different mycotoxins. including potentially toxin metabolites.

We require the supplier to perform a tailored sampling study of the current cat food market, to include 40 products. In discussion and with advice from the FSA and FSS, the supplier will choose approximately half of the products that are the largest sellers
/ brands within the marketplace. The remaining 15 - 20 products will be from other smaller and potentially niche producers (e.g. products containing insect protein). It is required that approximately half of the products are wet and half dry. Where possible up to 10 products should be sought from Scottish retailers.

Organisation Name: Surrey and Borders Partnership NHS Foundation Trust
Title: VAT Consultancy Services
Description:
Call-off deliverables: VAT Report (Phase 1)
Liaison with the contractor (Phase 2)
Letters to HMRC (Phase 3)
Zero rating certificate (Phase 4)
Document to set out matters to be done to
protect the position (Phase 5)

Phase 1 - Establishing the scope for zero rating of the Mount View Street Hospital
Â· Gathering the information required to understand the intended project in detail - this typically involves discussions with capital projects managers/teams and personnel who will be involved in the day to day running of the building (e.g., psychologists) and review of any available business cases.
Â· Reviewing floor plans and room configurations together with the operational aspects of the buildings.
Â· A review of the indicators of zero rating arising from the Pennine Care VAT case decision (plus other relevant case law precedent and HMRC guidance) and its applicability to the project's circumstances.
Â· Preparation of a VAT reports of our findings and recommendations regarding the availability of zero rating and the conditions to be met.
Â· Discussion of our reports with the Trust in order for you to understand the recommendations and in order to inform any decision to proceed.
Phase 2 - Agreeing zero rating with the contractor
Â· All liaison with the contractor (Kier) and the Trust in order to seek the contractor's agreement to zero rating in relation to the project.
Â· Advice regarding certification requirements for the project, where zero rating applies in full or in part.
Â· A meeting with the contractor during this phase in order to discuss the circumstances relating to the issue of the zero rating certificate.
Phase 3 - Agreeing zero rating with HMRC
Â· Preparation of the initial letter to HMRC seeking their agreement to full or partial zero rating.
Â· Assistance in responding to HMRC's requests for information.
Phase 4 - Advice regarding securing a refund of any VAT overcharged by Kier 
Â· In the event of success in phases 1 to 3, we will provide any assistance required in
respect of the quantum and procedure for obtaining a refund of any VAT charged at the standard rate which should be zero rated.
Phase 5 - Protecting zero rating
Â· This will involve a walk through the operational processes recommended to test adequacy and report on practical steps that can be taken to protect the position achieved.
BDO LLP is not (unless otherwise agreed in writing) responsible for:
a) providing legal, commercial or other advice outside the scope of the Engagement (including, but not limited to, your decision as to whether or not to obtain such advice);
b) reviewing (or otherwise being responsible for) the services provided by any other professional advisers retained by you (or who could have been retained by you); or
c) providing any other services beyond the scope of the Engagement.
Sussex Partnership NHS Foundation Trust is responsible for:
a) Providing any required information in a timely manner

Title: Contract for Somewhere Safe to Stay
Description:
This contract is for Somewhere Safe to Stay (ssts) beds based within County Durham.  Durham County Council requires a total of 9 (ssts) somewhere safe to stay beds based at various locations dispersed across County Durham which is to be provided by a number of Providers. 

Therefore, the Council intends to contract with successful Providers with individual supported accommodation projects who are able to provide at least 1 ssts bed and a maximum of 3 ssts beds for this provision.  Each of the individual ssts bed spaces must be identified, named and held by the Provider solely for use for referrals to be made by DCC's rough sleeper team when needed.  Each individual bed space must be available for the entire period of 1st July 2022 to 31st March 2024 on 24 hours/7 days a week basis for DCC's contract.  

Please download the tender documents for free for full details of requirements via the Procontract NEPO Portal WWW.nepo.org using Procontract Reference DN610723
 
 For additional guidance on how to submit your response through the NEPO Portal, please visit the NEPO website training section at https://www.nepo.org/suppliers/learn to access the Navigating the Portal suite of videos. These also include useful information on how to manage your online ProContract account. 

If you have any problems accessing or uploading your documents via the system please contact the NEPO helpdesk as detailed below. The E-tendering System Support is provided by the NEPO portal administration organisation Proactis.

Title: Chantry Centre Multi-Storey Car Park - Public Safety Fencing
Description:
Floors 5 and 5A of the multi-storey car park have been identified as an area of concern following a recent suicide prevention risk assessment of the site.

The intention of the new fencing is to prevent anyone from gaining access to the edge of the top deck of the car park by way of a complete 2.5m high barrier in all locations. The contractor must ensure that any ledges or foot holds are avoided as well as any means to bypass the fencing where if this is the case (for example adjacent stairwells where the profile of the building chamfers in) infills may be required.

The contractor is to price for the supply and installation of new hot dip and galvanised (to BS EN ISO 1461:1999) cold rolled steel palisade fencing as described in this schedule of works and in any accompanying documents provided.

The Main Contractor is required to programme and co-ordinate the work of any subcontractors and should plan for the works to be completed in 6 weeks.

Title: West Bromwich Urban Greening - Cultural Programme - AWARD
Description:
Sandwell Metropolitan Borough Council is seeking to appoint a suitably qualified cultural arts organisation to deliver a programme of cultural and communities activities as part of the West Bromwich - Urban Greening project between April 2022 and April 2025.  
      
      The Urban Greening project formed part of Town Investment Plan for West Bromwich that was submitted to MHCLG in Autumn 2020. Heads of Terms were agreed with SMBC in Spring 2021 and Full Business Cases are currently being prepared. The Urban Greening scheme will focus on West Bromwich Town Centre Green Public Realm improvements and a cultural programme is proposed to run alongside the Capital Development Works.
       
      The overall scheme consists of a number of components:
      - Public Realm upgrades - Princess Parade, West Bromwich
      - New green links along Bull Street, West Bromwich 
      - Cultural Programme
